article:
I remember my first Christmas party with Grandma.I remember the day when my big sister dropped the bomb: "There is no Santa Claus," she laughed."Even dummies know that!"
  I fled to Grandma because I knew she always told me  the truth  .After I told her everything, she said "No Santa Claus? Don't believe it. Now,   put on  your coat, and let's
go."
  "Go? Go where?" I asked.
  "Where"  turned out  to be the General Store.As we walked through its doors, Grandma   _  me ten dollars.That was a lot in those days."Take this money and buy something for   someone who  needs it.I'll wait for you in the car." 
  The store seemed big and  _  , full of people hurrying
to finish their Christmas shopping.For a few moments I just stood there,  _  , holding
that bill, wondering what to buy, and who on earth to buy it for.
  Suddenly I thought of Bobbie who sat right behind me.I remembered he didn't have a coat.I fingered the bill with growing   _  .I would buy Bobbie a coat.
  "Is this a Christmas present for someone?" the lady behind the   _  asked me kindly, as I laid my ten dollars down
  "Yes," I replied shyly."It's...for Bobbie."
  The nice lady smiled at me.I didn't get any   _  , but she put the coat in a bag
and wished me a Merry Christmas.
  That evening, Grandma helped me   _  the coat and
wrote, "To Bobby, From Santa Claus" on it.Then she   _  me over to Bobbie's house.
  Grandma parked down the street from Bobbie's house, and she and I crept  _  and hid in the  _  .Then Grandma gave me a sign."All right, Santa Claus, get going."
  I took a deep  _  , dashed for his front door, threw the
present down, pounded his doorbell and flew back to the safety.Together we   _  breathlessly
in the darkness for the front door to open.Finally it   _  , and there stood Bobbie.
  Forty years haven't dimmed the thrill of those   _  spent
shivering, beside my grandma, in Bobbie's bushes.  That night   ,  I realized: Santa was alive and well, and we were   _  his team.
